text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Kuwait's press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Kuwait arrests seven Iranian infiltrators. The arrest brings the number of Iranians trying to illegally enter Kuwait to 46 in one week.
- Trade Minister Jassem al-Mudaf left to the United Arab Emirates to take part in Gulf Arab industrialists conference.

- Finance Minister Nasser al-Rodhan says Kuwait Investment Authority (KIA), the state investment arm, to complete its privatisation programme by end of 1999. KIA is managing the sale of state stakes in some 60 local firms. It has sold stakes in about 22 firms worth some $2.4 million since 1994.
- Britain reiterates commitment to the security of the Gulf, British Foreign Secretay Robin Cook says.
- Interior Ministry continues efforts to seize unlicensed weapons.
- Health scheme needs 50 dinars yearly, top insurance executive says. Kuwait plans to impose a health insurance fee of about 50-dinar on its 1.2 million expatriate residents.
- MPs seek investigation into Kuwait Petroleum Corporation's (KPC) investments decisions.
- Parliament's human rights committee urges closure of deportation centre.
